item.title: Δ
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“SirPali, post:8, topic:327496”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=423887.msg3112993#msg3112993 date=1264710475]
Is this kinda of like modulus?
[/quote]

Not really, it’s better to explain with a larger number then what Blargh did.

The modulo of 14 and 4 = (14%4) = 2
The delta of 4 and 14 = 10 (The change between 4 and 14). So basicly var B - var A.

OT: Interesting. Threadtitles with symbols most people have never seen before, get a lot more views then other threads.[/quote]
Yea, his small number was confusing. Because 7%5 is two as well.

Read full topic

item.description:
@SirPali wrote:

Davidi2:

Is this kinda of like modulus?

Not really, it’s better to explain with a larger number then what Blargh did.

The modulo of 14 and 4 = (14%4) = 2
The delta of 4 and 14 = 10 (The change between 4 and 14). So basicly var B - var A.

OT: Interesting. Threadtitles with symbols most people have never seen before, get a lot more views then other threads.

item.title: Δ
item.dc:creator: @SirPali SirPali
item.description:
@SirPali wrote:

Hmm.
I think I can remember from High school, that Delta is the change in something right? Like the change in t(time), x, y etc.
As far as my java knowledge is concerned, and as far as I can find in my Java book for school, I have actually no clue how to use delta in Java.

What i DO know though, is that the java Calendar uses delta. Maybe you can find some further information on that

Just out of curiosity though, what are you planning to use it for?

Anyway, Good luck!

Read full topic

item.title: Δ

item.description:
@_BBLLAARRGGHH wrote:

Delta. It’s complicated to explain. If you don’t know what it is, then it’s best you don’t bother posting, because it’s confusing if you don’t know it properly.

And SirPali, I actually want to know what to write for it, as I’ve never used delta before in Java, so I dunno what it’s supposed to look like even vaguely.

Read full topic

item.title: Δ
item.dc:creator: @SirPali SirPali
item.description:
@SirPali wrote:

int A = 3; int B = 7; int C = A + B; System.out.println($C);

I’m guessing you want the delta between A and B here. Wouldn’t that be

$(A,B)

or something.

Not sure if it works like that, but it seems more logical then your example.

Read full topic

item.title: Δ

item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

[quote="–BBLLAARRGGHH–, post:1, topic:327496"]Hey, I’m looking for some help on how the delta is used with Java. Delta/$/Δ means the change, e.g. the delta from 5 to 7 is 2.
I’m looking for how to integrate this into some code. Sorta’ like

[code]
int A = 3;
int B = 7;
int C = A + B;

System.out.println($C);[/code]

Thanks in advance.[/quote]

What are you talking about?

Read full topic

item.title: Δ

item.description:
@_BBLLAARRGGHH wrote:

Hey, I’m looking for some help on how the delta is used with Java. Delta/$/Δ means the change, e.g. the delta from 5 to 7 is 2.
I’m looking for how to integrate this into some code. Sorta’ like

[code]
int A = 3;
int B = 7;
int C = A + B;

System.out.println($C);[/code]

Thanks in advance.
